comments.raw_text:
I'm not sure if this is actually possible, but it could be worth investigating further.

This extension lets us map memory from the bc-cat driver into our process, render into it and then use this as a texture.

User Guide: http://processors.wiki.ti.com/index.php/OpenGLES_Texture_Streaming_-_bc-cat_User_Guide

Example Code: https://gstreamer.ti.com/gf/project/gleslayer/scmsvn/?action=browse&path=%2Ftrunk%2FPackages%2FOMAP3_Graphics_SDK%2FGLESLAYER_SGXPERF_20%2Fsgxperf_gles20_vg.cpp&revision=58&view=markup (search for _ENABLE_TEST8)

On my Samsung Galaxy S, I don't actually have /dev/bc_cat, but I do have a similar named s3c_bc file. This looks to be the source code for this file (http://jhulst.com/publicsvn/captivate/3d/services4/3rdparty/s3c_bc/) and the s3c_bc_params.h file looks to contain what I'd expect.

Vlad thinks that we may have permissions issues trying to the ioctl calls.

The mapped memory is also done using MAP_SHARED, I'm not sure what this means with regard to having multiple processes. If we load the driver into both processes and map in both, can they both share data? This would be a huge win if we could map into content and still use it as a texture in chrome.
